title: Leopard Gecko Enclosure Setup Guide: Complete Housing Requirements
description: Complete enclosure setup guide for leopard geckos covering dimensions, terrestrial layout design, heating zones, equipment checklist, and naturalistic desert habitat creation.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Essential Housing for Leopard Geckos
content.content: Leopard geckos are terrestrial (ground-dwelling) lizards from the arid grasslands and semi-deserts of South Asia. Unlike arboreal species, they need enclosures that prioritize floor space over height, with multiple temperature zones, hiding spots, and climbing opportunities among rocks. This guide covers everything you need to know about setting up the perfect leopard gecko enclosure.
Leopard geckos are terrestrial and need horizontal space to roam, hunt, and thermoregulate. While they're skilled climbers in rocky terrain, enclosures should be wider than tall.

content.text: Minimum Enclosure Sizes:

rows: Adequate floor space for thermal gradient and multiple hides
Reduces competition, provides space for multiple basking/hiding areas
Easier to monitor feeding, transition to adult size at 6-12 months

content.content: Never house leopard geckos in enclosures smaller than 36×18×18. Common '20-gallon long' tanks (30×12×12) are too narrow to establish proper temperature gradients. Height is less critical—18" is sufficient, though 24" allows for rock stacks.
Different enclosure materials offer advantages for desert species. Leopard geckos need good ventilation and the ability to maintain a hot basking zone without overheating the entire enclosure.

content.text: Material Options:

rows: Advanced keepers, colder climates, better insulation
Custom builds, bioactive setups, visual appeal
Not recommended—can't maintain humidity for humid hide

content.content: Front-opening glass terrariums are ideal for beginners. Top-opening tanks can be used but stress terrestrial species that perceive threats from above. Avoid screen enclosures entirely—insufficient heat retention.

For complete guidance on creating thermal gradients and selecting temperature monitoring equipment, see our Understanding Thermal Gradients and Temperature Monitoring Equipment guides. Leopard geckos require a basking surface of 94-97°F and a cool zone of 70-77°F.
Leopard geckos are secretive and require multiple hides at different temperature zones. Three hides minimum: warm, cool, and humid.

content.text: Essential Hide Setup:

rows: Enclosed, single entrance, fits gecko snugly
Secure warm retreat, sleep spot, digestion

content.text: Humid Hide Construction:

rows: Plastic hide box, tupperware with entrance cut
Damp sphagnum moss, paper towels, coco fiber
Should feel damp to touch, not dripping
Prevents humid hide from drying out too quickly

content.content: A humid hide is NOT optional—it's required equipment for leopard geckos. Without 70-80% humidity access, they experience stuck shed (especially on toes, leading to toe loss), dehydration, and eye problems.
Leopard geckos do best on naturalistic arid substrates that allow for digging, retain some moisture (for humid hide support), and mimic their native semi-desert habitat.

content.text: Substrate Options (2-4" depth):

rows: DIY Arid Mix (40% topsoil + 40% sand + 20% excavator clay)
Budget-friendly, mimics natural habitat, allows digging
Fine sand, good for digging, needs moisture management
Premium bioactive substrate with beneficial microbes
Easy to clean, heat-absorbing, but no digging/enrichment

content.content: Avoid calcium sand (causes impaction), pure fine sand without binder (collapses burrows), reptile carpet (toe snags), and wood shavings (aromatic oils toxic). With proper heat, hydration, and UVB, naturalistic substrates are safe.
Leopard geckos are skilled rock climbers in the wild. Provide stacked stones, branches, and ledges to encourage natural behaviors and exercise.

content.text: Enrichment Items:

rows: Under heat lamp, stacked for climbing access
Mid to warm zone, create hide openings and ledges
Horizontal ground hides, vertical for climbing
Aloe, haworthia, echeveria—arid tolerant, low water

content.content: Leopard geckos love to climb—provide ledges and rock stacks up to 8-12" high. Ensure stacks are stable (use aquarium-safe silicone to bond rocks if needed) to prevent collapse injuries.

content.text: Day-by-Day Setup Process:

rows: Install lights, heat lamp, thermometers. Test all equipment without gecko.
Add 2-4" substrate, position rocks/cork bark, create stable formations.
Install warm hide under basking, cool hide on opposite end, humid hide near water dish.
Run setup for 48 hours. Verify basking surface 94-97°F, cool end 70-77°F.
Add climbing branches, background plants, food/water dishes.
Place gecko in cool end during evening. Monitor for 48 hours, minimal handling.

content.text: Mistakes to Avoid:

rows: Too narrow for proper thermal gradient
Use minimum 36×18×18—width is critical for temperature zones
Stuck shed, toe loss, dehydration, eye caps stuck
Humid hide with 70-80% humidity is mandatory equipment
Gecko forced to choose between temperature and security
Minimum 3 hides: warm, cool, humid (plus additional optional)
Heat mat as sole heat source
No overhead basking, unnatural heat source
Heat lamp is primary—mat only supplemental if needed
Use 75-100w halogen to achieve 94-97°F surface temp
Heat lamp on one end only—cool end should be 70-77°F
Add rock stacks, branches, ledges—aim for 50% floor coverage

content.content: Cohabitation is controversial and NOT recommended for beginners. Leopard geckos can be territorial, and injuries from fighting are common.

content.text: Cohabitation Guidelines:

rows: Competition for basking, food aggression, tail loss, stress
Breeding stress, male aggression, females may fight
Severe fighting, injuries, death—males are highly territorial

content.content: Males should NEVER be housed together—they will fight to the death. Signs of failed cohabitation: tail loss, bite marks, weight loss (one gecko not eating), one gecko always hiding. Separate immediately if any aggression is observed.
Bioactive enclosures use live plants and cleanup crew (CUC) to create a self-sustaining desert ecosystem. Advanced option requiring specific setup.

content.text: Bioactive Components:

rows: Prevents substrate waterlogging in humid hide area
Supports plant growth in low-UVB environment

content.content: Bioactive leopard gecko setups are challenging due to low humidity requirements. Focus CUC activity near humid hide where moisture is higher. Allow 4-6 weeks for ecosystem to establish before adding gecko.
